title: Are scales necessary when learning to play piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: Knowing the scales (particularly where the black keys must be played) makes it easier to play any song on the piano by ear and in any key signature. Most songs will also modulate between different keys, so knowing the scales will help you play the melody by ear without striking a sour note. In theory, however, it may be possible to play by ear without knowing your scales if you play all songs in the key of C (no black keys) or A major (only one black key), while remembering via muscle memory to play the notes at III-IV and VII-VIII as adjacent keys when playing in a major key and playing the notes at II-III and V-VI as adjacent keys when playing in a minor key - particularly when playing melodies on the right hand. When playing chords on the left hand, put into muscle memory the finger spacing between pinky and middle finger for playing note interval 3, and finger spacing between pinky and thumb for playing note interval 5 to help you identify the root note by feel from below the melodic note. If the pinky happens to bump up against a black key, then play the black key as the root note. Next, form a fixed claw with three fingers to play the root note and the notes at 5 and 8 note intervals above the root note. If and when the middle finger happens to touch and bump up against a black key, then play that note as a sharp/flat key. To put all of these pointers together, here’s how one can in theory learn to play piano by ear without actually learning to play the scales: 1) Memorize the melody so you can hum the whole song in your head 2) Play the song on the right hand in key of C (see video for more details) 3) Sight & locate the melodic note (played on the main down beats) you are about to play on your right hand & immediately locate & play the bass note at 1, 3 or 5 intervals BELOW the melodic note **KNOWING WHICH BASS NOTE SHOULD BE PLAYED ON A BLACK KEY** 4) Play or roll simple chords from notes at 1-5-8 intervals ABOVE each bass note (or 1–3–5 if your familiar with your scales) **KNOWING WHICH NOTES IN THE CHORD TO PLAY ON A BLACK KEY**

As has been said in previous answers, scales are great exercises to develop strength and sound memory through playing. However, what I lack seeing in the answers here are the fun facts of scales. These are the benefits that I tell my students about: They are useful. if you would ever like to arrange or write music, scales, along with arpeggios, are the building blocks of most embellishments. To make a piece sound pretty, you can use scales to climb between notes, while bringing out the distinct sound of the piano (or guitar, harp, violin etc.).They are impressive. If you look up people playing scales at 240 rpm or greater, that’s all they really need. Even some performances of scales or exercises from Hanon’s are said to stir audiences with awe. There are different arrangements of scales, too, as in scales in thirds, in octaves, etc. These are pretty challenging but very rewarding, just like a high video-game level, if you don’t mind me saying.They can be fun, too, I swear! Honest! I love scales, just like I love jumping jacks. When they start working, when they come naturally, when you don’t have to think so much about them anymore, they can be sort of mind-clearing, relaxing, and entertaining. Mildly challenging, just like Candy Crush. And when you’re learning them, you’re really flexing your brain muscles, increasing your coordination.They are didactic. They’re the kind of exercise that your mind can always look back and refer to when playing any style of music, especially jazz, pop, and classical. They’re used often in so many pieces of music, and when you get to that point of the song, you’ll be like “wow, that was easy,” and it sounded great too!There aren’t only 24! There’s a whole world of scales, actually, from different cultures, full of history and tradition. The cool part is that some sound so out there, so unique, that just by playing the scale, you can feel like you have taken a step into another culture, another world. I.e. all of the arabic traditional scales (ie Maqam), indian ragas, pentatonic, etc.Overall, scales are the heart of composing music, from everywhere around the world. Learning these scales will make creating music so easy and natural, it’ll be like eating ice cream. You’ll be impressive, creative, brainy, and in touch with the greats, like Mozart, like Edvard Grieg, like Hans Zimmer.

The conventional fingering on a C major scale over four octaves is: RH 123123412312341231234123123454321321432132143213214321321 LH 543213214321321432132143213212312341231234123123412312345 If you take away fingers 123 and 4 you have:- RH——————————————-5—————————————— LH 5————————————————————————————5 D, E, G and A use the same fingering, so if you play those five scales you will have hardly exercised your fifth finger at all. Of the remaining scales most are similar and some don’t use the fifth finger at all. Now look at any conventional piece of music by any of the great composers and make a note of the fingering. You will see that the fifth finger is used an awful lot, just as much as the other fingers if not more. So the fifth finger, the least strong finger, the one that needs the attention is almost ignored. And the next weakest finger, the fourth is exercised half as much as the remaining three as essentially all scales break down as a 1231234 configuration in some form or other. Then look at where scales actually occur in pieces of music and observe that very often the fingering is quite different to the scale for logistical reasons. As I pointed out, five scales have identical fingerings as do many of the remaining ones. I personally don’t see a lot of point in playing G if you can play C unless you need to familiarise yourself with the keys, although it’s not rocket science remembering to sharpen the F. Such knowledge can be obtained without drilling the fingers unnecessarily. Don’t get me started on minor scales…

I dont think so, but it isn't a popular opinion. Each time you practice something on the piano, you are learning a new technique, whether they are scales, arpeggios, or passages from pieces. If you master scales, you will become very good at passages that are played most similar to the scale that you learned. Some of the skill will carry over to passages that are a bit different. But practicing passages from pieces can also improve your skills that can carry over to other pieces. From my personal experience, the technique I gained from mastering actual pieces carried over to other pieces and back to scales much better than the technique gained from practicing scales, where the carry over to pieces was not as efficient. Most importantly, my practicing pieces that have scale-like passages (Clementi, Bach, etc) enabled me to master scales with respectable speed without my actually spending much time on the scales. The time I would have wasted on practicing scales I actually mastered numerous pieces. ***Try it yourself.Practice scales for awhile and see how much that improves your technique when playing pieces. Then take some tine off from scales and practice several technically challenging pieces and see ho much that improves your technique for other pieces.

Not just unnecessary, counterproductive and generally harmful. Facts backed by math, science and the untold thousands of skilled players who never practice scales. So never practice scales on the piano as it is not a string instrument, it’s a percussion instrument. The evil of scales exist to aid students in learning to read Crypto, the outdated Classic music notation that Mozart used. With its sharps, flats and key signatures Classic Notation is a form of cryptography that requires each and every player to individually decrypt the encrypted playback information. As it happens, I’m the mathematician who proved the failings of standard piano methods with my invention of both the ‘faz‘ and faz music notation. The faz being the newest member of the piano family that also doubles as a scientific instrument. The faz combines two well known keyboards that are both based on the number 12. The electronic piano keyboard and the touch tone telephone. The 12 keys of the telephone are wired to remotely operate 12 consecutive piano keys. Faz music notation being nothing more than phone numbers of various lengths with the # and * keys included with the digits 0–9. What the faz and its notation prove is that with a better notation system anyone can start pressing piano keys and make music come out of the box with almost no instruction at all.

It really depends on what you are trying to accomplish, and where you are in terms of learning. All piano teachers would recommend learning scales, and for good reason - many of the skills that are important for learning piano are developed in practicing scales: Independent finger movementMuscle memory for spacings between keysPromoting good finger and hand shapeLearning how to manage accidentalsIncreasing staminaImproving the dexterityAll-round greater strength and finesseEasy pieces are very manageable without scales, however. If you are just looking to play something nice and beginner, such as Fur Elise, then scales are not strictly necessary. Practicing technical exercises are very boring and time-consuming, but the long-term gain is immeasurable. While not necessary, scales are something that every serious piano player devotes a great portion of their time into developing, and one I would seriously recommend too.

Well it depends how well you want to learn to play... I used to detest scales when I first began learning piano, but now I like them. Which is lucky as I need to play them each day for practice. The thing most teachers forget to mention is that you don't have to play tons of different scales every day. That is just silly and a complete waist of time. Just choose two or maybe three scales to practice each day, then you will remember them better. Maybe one major and one minor scale. Also do the same for arpeggios. Maybe if you are still a begginner play the same two scales each day for a week. This way you will rembember the scales better and can move onto some new ones. Then eventually you will know them all. Also C major is not the easiest scale to start with, it has no black keys, and is very uncomfortable compared to many easier ones like E major or B major or F# major. C major is one of the most difficult overall. Of course many teachers begin with this because it makes sense when you study music theory at the same time.

Not as a technical exercise, no. They are an essential part of Classical and Baroque compositions, as well as large parts of the Romantic repertoire. I am in no way suggesting that a scale isn’t necessary when in context. But as an exercise? Total waste of time. The main reason for this is that the fingering on a plain old scale will almost always differ from that of the scale in a piece of music. The type of finger movement that we use to execute a scalar pattern can be learned through actual music. It also doesn’t drive students insane. If someone wants to learn scales, by all means, do it. It’s not going to be harmful, but just don’t rely on it too heavily. To learn scales, look no further than Mozart.

Yes, but the standard piano keyboard is a lame device. You can try instead an uniform keyboard and practice 4 (possibly even only 2) scales instead of 24! You’ll then make much faster progress and play more intuitively. Such keyboards never succeeded though they have been around for more than 100 years. This is due to inertia and ignorance among other factors, but things are beginning to change thanks to the information age. Be aware that finding an uniform piano keyboard is currently not easy, but you might be interested by some commercial alternatives, e.g. The dualo principle  - dualo . For more information, you can start here: Jankó keyboard or even check my own page The Bilinear Uniform Chromatic Keyboard (BUCK) also available in French and Italian. Below are quotes from famous pianists about the Jankó keyboard: This invention will have replaced the present piano keyboard in fifty years' time! -(Franz Liszt – His prediction was wrong however.)  If I were to begin my career anew it would be on this keyboard. (Arthur Rubinstein)

Not so much necessary but more of a required skill that speeds the progress of cognitive understanding of the keys to help sight reading. They’re also an objective sign of evidence that you are not just learning the piece by ear and do indeed understand the musical theory of your level (or higher). They speed up the process of engraining the keys into your head and improve certain hand techniques that naturally come with it. They’re one of the requirements in examination when passing a grade, to show what you know in terms of how the notes work. This expands into melodic minor scales that combine major and minor together and incorporate the relative major of that minor scale. Can a person become a concert pianist without learning scales? I think so. However, much more would need to be learned on paper rather than just practising a technique to save you time and improve your fingering skills, so the learning I think would be much harder in the long-run.

Yes.  I don't want you to spend all your time going through the scales, of course, but you need to run through the scale associated with the key of the piece you are going to learn.  There will be scale passages in classical music (and in popular pieces, as well.)  Think of the 1st mvt. of Mozart's Sonata in C.  Scale runs!   Generally, students use scales as part of a daily warm-up.  Don't do them mindlessly.  Do a one- or two-octave runthrough of whichever scale you've been assigned that week every day when you start to practice.  This is also a good time to do any exercises, be they Hanon, Czerny, or something your teacher has clipped out of a current piece.  Then your fingers will be warmed up and you can launch into practicing your piece(s).  Don't stress about it!  But it's good to know the scale and also the I-iv-V chord cadence for every key you're going to play in.

No, I have never done scales. There are many pianist that do hours of mechanical ejercices and I don't think there is any difference in what they can play and what I can play. If you have an arpeggio you find the way to play it, if you have a scale you solve the problem with correct fingering. I think there is an advance in not doing scales: Instead of thinking in a sequence of notes, a scale, an arpeggio, you can focus in each sound and find fingering that favours the way it must be. Not every scale should sound the same way, not every 16th note should be exactly as the previous one. Finaly, as well as there are great pianists doing hours of scales, there are many bad pianist doing the same hours of scales.

I am a guitarist who decided to learn to play piano too.  I believe you have to mix fun with scales and exercises.  The split is up to you, but what is the point of mechanical practicing of scales and theory, if you are not moving towards a goal, like learning a song you really want to play.  The rote practice eventually makes the learning of a new piece easier or improvisation easier, but what is the point in piano or music or life of practicing boring and mechanical things endlessly without enjoying yourself, messing around, learning your favourite songs, writing a song etc....  Otherwise, what's the point?

Scales can be a pain, but in the grand scheme of things they help with piano playing and music in general. Not only do they help your fingers develop a feel for the keys, but they also help you understand other aspects of music. Scales help with key signatures, chords, sight reading, and your overall playing ability. Eventually you'll get to a point where they are just a quick exercise you use to warm up, but they can be very annoying when you first start playing. They are also often something people test you on if you're looking for a career in music. Overall, scales are not exactly necessary, but extremely helpful and can improve your playing ability drastically.

If for no other reason than as practice works, yes. Scales would be a necessary step in learning what different keys are made of. Transposing from one key to another helps when doing vocal accompaniment. Scales and keys lead one into chording, which allows one to accompany other musicians when there is no written sheet music for guidance. So….back to the original question, the answer is still yes, as one thing is tied into another. Plus, for limbering & finger exercises, scales can't be discounted.

While what everyone has said is true, one invaluable benefit of playing scales is the "warming up" of your fingers every time.  Nervous before a performance? Playing in the winter?  5 min. (or more) of repeating all the scales fairly fast will get your fingers in tip-top shape.  This is especially necessary when you're playing technically difficult pieces.  Scales are the backbone of many instruments, not just piano.  It is an important part of music theory, and understanding the scales forms the necessary foundation for being able to analyze music.  As others have said, it develops technique as well...

You know, there seem to be a lot of people saying that first you have to learn this, then you have to learn that, and a, b, c, d, g, q, and z. Then, you can start playing piano. Let me tell you something, if you love music, then you will be just fine. I first learned piano in second grade. Soon after, I fell in love with Rock n’ Roll music. My system for learning a song is riff, verse, solo, details/improvements. I have about 20 songs that I can play off the top of my head. All of them were learned basically in this way. I have found, just by learning songs that I want to play, that if you love to play the piano, you will pick up on everything else later. When I started learning the intro riff to “Right Now” by Van Halen, I wasn’t altogether to good at piano. That song alone taught me a lot about my instrument. Listening to my favorite band, Avenged Sevenfold, has taught me a ton about music composition. The point is, you will pick stuff up on your own. Just stick with it, and it will come.

Whether you are playing piano or any other instrument with capacity for melody, much of your music will be constructed from the intervallic patterns of scales and arpeggios. You will have fragments of scales of any length, beginning and ending on any note of the scale. You might wish to tackle a piece of music without reference to the scales from which it is built.  However it is much more efficient and much more transferable to learn both the scales and also fragmentation exercises based upon these scales.  From the time invested in that, you will be better equipped not only to learn the piece that you started out to learn, but also many others.

Scales teach the fingerings that you will use when playing in the different keys, that is vital. When you sit before a piece of music and look at the key signature, you will know exactly which “accidentals”, the black keys, are to be played. Knowing this is like knowing the times tables in that you do not have to figure the answers out every time.jw P.S. Music, despite the public fantasy, is not easy. j

Scales and arpeggios form the foundation of Western Music. Could you learn to play the piano without mastering this skill set? Yes, but your study would be very inefficient. Since music is built upon scales and broken chords (arpeggios) every time you encounter them in music, you would have to figure them out. Furthermore, by concentrating a portion of your practice on scales and arpeggios, it gives you the opportunity to focus your attention on how your hands and fingers work without the additional distraction of all the complexities involved in a musical composition.

SCALES ARE A FUNDAMENTAL FOR ALL MUSICIANS FOR SEVERAL REASONS. The notes of our melodies and harmonies are chosen from and kept organized by the scales. This ORDER is very important simply because it sounds good, and also to give meaning and understanding to the notes; not just straight memorization. Scales are a big part of our music note patterns, and also a big part of our technique in nimble and knowledgeable finger movements.

101% yes. It develops how even you can play your notes, and many pieces include scales and arpeggios of all types. It is so much more efficient to learn all the scales and memorize and apply them to your pieces, rather than learn each scale while you are learning your piece. While practicing scales, it is a good time to practice your hand positions. You will also learn some basic music theory. So, all in all, learning scales will only benefit you.

Honestly? No. I was playing since I was 7, and I only started scales 2 years ago when I started to get more serious. That being said, up until 2 years I was pretty rubbish, whereas now I am so much better. If you wanna play for you because you like how it sounds and don't care what other people say, go ahead and skip scales. If you wanna be good... Yeah, you'll need scales. Sorry bud.

If you are learning piano, get excited about all of it. Scales, chords, rhythm, genres, practice schedules,  finger exercises, theory, everything. consume it all like a four course meal. Otherwise, you are wasting your time. Go learn gardening or oil painting or something that does excite you.

Although scales may seem rather boring, they are extremely important. To be able to play the piano well you need to have good dexterity in your fingers, and the best way to build up that strength is by practicing scales. yet perhaps the most difficult instrument to master. ... To compensate, the piano is a polyphonic instrument. This means that it can play many notes at once, thus increasing the complexity many times over. Similarly, playing the piano necessitates coordinating the hands, which are mirror images of each other. Go to my Profile and you can find all about Play Piano material there...

i would say that they are important but chords and correct fingering are more important. also one of the easiest things to do that is also one of the most important is to do improvisation. try improvising with the sustain pedal and using only black keys and doing improvisation with c blues (which is what my old piano teacher taught me [also he is the best piano teacher ever]) also i would suggest your major scales in this order first: c g d a e b f (b and f should only be done once you are very good with your other scales and good with the fingering) i hope you have a very nice day and i hope my answer helped

Scales are partly necessary when learning to play; you won't really need them until you begin to play pieces with scale patterns and they will make a lot more sense then. The C-scale is a good scale to start, with no sharps or flats (unless C-minor), so it is easy to learn and master, leading to other scales. Your tetrachords will also help greatly when learning other scales.

You can get away with it for a little while. Eventually you have to know all of them with both hands - both parallel and contrary motion. A serious teaching studio will not let you in if you can’t do it. Some of the people who don’t practice scales are a child prodigy with perfect pitch anyway. For them perhaps it is a waste of time; but, everyone else has to do it.

Yes, they are very important They are like a backbone to not just piano but for all musical instruments. Not just Major scales but minor too and all the flats and sharps scales. All the natural, harmonic and melodic minor scales. You cannot hope to be a good pianist without know the scales.

Definitely yes, for both the development of technique and the comprehension of musical theory, structure, and basic harmonic sequence (analyzing the chords used underneath the melody), all of which assist in memorization of music and its structure.

Absolutely. From a technical standpoint, they teach you keys, chords, modes, and arpeggios. They’re also simple exercises that can improve your finger strength and how fast you can move your fingers up and down the keys.
There are tons of scales out there! All of them are a variation of the standard major scale ( Ionian mode ) If you get that one solid in all 12 Keys you’ll be off to a great start.
